title: R43557
content: The first section of the report outlines the FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process, including the initial request submission, hearings by House and Senate Subcommittees, markups by House Subcommittee and Committee on Appropriations, passage of H.R. 4487 by the House, markup and reporting of H.R. 4487 by the Senate Appropriations Committee, and enactment of continuing appropriations resolutions (P.L. 113-164). The report discusses the FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process, including the enactment of various appropriations resolutions and the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015. It also covers prior year actions, funding, budget requests, hearings, and funding levels for FY2014 and FY2015. The FY2015 U.S. Budget includes a request for $4.471 billion in new budget authority for legislative branch activities. Representative Moran proposed a $25 per day housing stipend. The FY2015 bill markup included an amendment proposed by Representative Moran for a $25 per day housing stipend for Members living 50 or more miles away from Washington, DC, which failed. The House of Representatives considered H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014, with eight amendments, including one by Representative Nugent to prohibit MRA funding for vehicle leasing, which failed by a vote of 196-221. An amendment to appropriate $500,000 for sexual harassment training for House offices was approved by voice vote. Another amendment to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden to FY2014 levels and transfer funds to a spending reduction account was also approved. An amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center by $243,000 failed by a vote of 207-212. Another amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund also failed. An amendment to prohibit funds from being used to deliver printed copies of the Statement of Disbursements of the House to any Member of the House was approved. The House passed H.R. 4487 by a vote of 402-14, with amendments including prohibiting funding for printed copies of the House daily calendar and failing to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment.
